prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity: We estimate the CO(4-3) line fluxes for the galaxies in our sample in the following way:
1) Calculate M_gas by 150*M_dust, where the dust mass comes from our SED fitting of the full galaxy spectrum through to the Herschel SPIRE bands. This M_gas/M_dust ratio is appropriate for local star-forming disc galaxies.
2) We convert M_gas to L_CO(1-0) assuming the Galactic conversion M_gas = 4.6*L_CO, which is a conservative value, since it predicts a lower CO luminosity than, e.g. a ULIRG-like conversion.
3) We assume a very conservative subthermal CO(4-3)/CO(1-0)=0.5 to predict the CO(4-3) luminosity and convert this to an integrated line flux at the redshift (from optical spectroscopy) of each galaxy. This yields log(L_CO(4-3))=9.5 in radio units, and integrated fluxes of~8 Jy km/s.
4) A 300 km/s wide line is assumed, and we assume the flux is equally distributed across the 3" size of the galaxies (from optical imaging), or 9 beams at our proposed 1" resolution. Therefore we calculate the peak line fluxes (per beam) of 3mJy. Note we have grouped the galaxies into three science goals where each sub-sample (faint, medium, bright) which can be observed with the same sensitivity.
We require 3-sigma detections in 50 km/s channels spanning the width of the line (thus giving a high significance detection of the integrated line). For log(M_dust/M_sun)~8.3 in the faint sample, and following the procedure above, we require a sensitivity of 1 mJy in 50 km/s channels.
Imaging: we will map 3"-size sources at 1" resolution, and even in the relatively short exposures required to reach our sensitivity requirements, there is sufficient uv-coverage to produce good maps with the current ALMA array.
Correlator setup: We will observe the CO(4-3) line in Band 7, using a bandwidth of 1.875 GHz (i.e. the coarsest spectral resolution FDM mode) and 0.976 MHz channel spacing (including online Hanning smoothing). We have conservatively assumed line widths to be 300 km/s, and we will bin the spectra to a final velocity resolution of 50 km/s as described above. Note that the redshift is known precisely.
Calibration: We will use standard calibration, and have groups sources that can share phase calibrators.
Bandpass accuracy: n/a
Data rate: n/a
Special constraints: none

Sensitivity: We estimate the CO(4-3) line fluxes for the galaxies in our sample in the following way:
1) Calculate M_gas by 150*M_dust, where the dust mass comes from our SED fitting of the full galaxy spectrum through to the Herschel SPIRE bands. This M_gas/M_dust ratio is appropriate for local star-forming disc galaxies.
2) We convert M_gas to L_CO(1-0) assuming the Galactic conversion M_gas = 4.6*L_CO, which is a conservative value, since it predicts a lower CO luminosity than, e.g. a ULIRG-like conversion.
3) We assume a very conservative subthermal CO(4-3)/CO(1-0)=0.5 to predict the CO(4-3) luminosity and convert this to an integrated line flux at the redshift (from optical spectroscopy) of each galaxy. This yields log(L_CO(4-3))=9.9 in radio units, and integrated fluxes of ~12 Jy km/s.
4) A 300 km/s wide line is assumed, and we assume the flux is equally distributed across the 3" size of the galaxies (from optical imaging), or 9 beams at our proposed 1" resolution. Therefore we calculate the peak line fluxes (per beam) of 7.5-9mJy. Note we have grouped the galaxies into three science goals where each sub-sample (faint, medium, bright) which can be observed with the same sensitivity.
We require 3-sigma detections in 50 km/s channels spanning the width of the line (thus giving a high significance detection of the integrated line). For log(M_dust/M_sun)~8.7 in the bright sample, and following the procedure above, we require a sensitivity of 2.5 mJy in 50 km/s channels.
Imaging: we will map 3"-size sources at 1" resolution, and even in the relatively short exposures required to reach our sensitivity requirements, there is sufficient uv-coverage to produce good maps with the current ALMA array.
Correlator setup: We will observe the CO(4-3) line in Band 7, using a bandwidth of 1.875 GHz (i.e. the coarsest spectral resolution FDM mode) and 0.976 MHz channel spacing (including online Hanning smoothing). We have conservatively assumed line widths to be 300 km/s, and we will bin the spectra to a final velocity resolution of 50 km/s as described above. Note that the redshift is known precisely.
Calibration: We will use standard calibration, and have groups sources that can share phase calibrators.
Bandpass accuracy: n/a
Data rate: n/a
Special constraints: none

Sensitivity: We estimate the CO(4-3) line fluxes for the galaxies in our sample in the following way:
1) Calculate M_gas by 150*M_dust, where the dust mass comes from our SED fitting of the full galaxy spectrum through to the Herschel SPIRE bands. This M_gas/M_dust ratio is appropriate for local star-forming disc galaxies.
2) We convert M_gas to L_CO(1-0) assuming the Galactic conversion M_gas = 4.6*L_CO, which is a conservative value, since it predicts a lower CO luminosity than, e.g. a ULIRG-like conversion.
3) We assume a very conservative subthermal CO(4-3)/CO(1-0)=0.5 to predict the CO(4-3) luminosity and convert this to an integrated line flux at the redshift (from optical spectroscopy) of each galaxy. This yields log(L_CO(4-3))=9.7 in radio units, and integrated fluxes of ~12 Jy km/s.
4) A 300 km/s wide line is assumed, and we assume the flux is equally distributed across the 3" size of the galaxies (from optical imaging), or 9 beams at our proposed 1" resolution. Therefore we calculate the peak line fluxes (per beam) of 4mJy. Note we have grouped the galaxies into three science goals where each sub-sample (faint, medium, bright) which can be observed with the same sensitivity.
We require 3-sigma detections in 50 km/s channels spanning the width of the line (thus giving a high significance detection of the integrated line). For log(M_dust/M_sun)~8.4 in the medium sample, and following the procedure above, we require a sensitivity of 1.5 mJy in 50 km/s channels.
Imaging: we will map 3"-size sources at 1" resolution, and even in the relatively short exposures required to reach our sensitivity requirements, there is sufficient uv-coverage to produce good maps with the current ALMA array.
Correlator setup: We will observe the CO(4-3) line in Band 7, using a bandwidth of 1.875 GHz (i.e. the coarsest spectral resolution FDM mode) and 0.976 MHz channel spacing (including online Hanning smoothing). We have conservatively assumed line widths to be 300 km/s, and we will bin the spectra to a final velocity resolution of 50 km/s as described above. Note that the redshift is known precisely.
Calibration: We will use standard calibration, and have groups sources that can share phase calibrators.
Bandpass accuracy: n/a
Data rate: n/a
Special constraints: none

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: One of the most promising proxies for describing the star formation 'mode' of galaxies is the ratio of dense, actively star-forming gas to the total bulk/quiescent cold molecular gas reservoir. Normal discs have dense-to-total gas mass ratios of a few per cent, whereas this this can be up to 30% in the most extreme starbursts. By measuring both the dense and bulk gas reservoir it is possible to gain a better understanding of the evolution of star formation efficiency and gas depletion timescales, both of which are key descriptors in all models of galaxy formation. In this proposal we aim to map the dense gas tracer CO(4-3) in a sample of z=0.35 'normal' (main sequence) galaxies selected from the H-ATLAS survey for which we are obtaining CO(1-0) and [CI](1-0), which are tracers of the bulk gas reservoir. We will map the distribution of dense gas in the galaxies and benchmark the diagnostic CO(4-3)/[CI](1-0) as a proxy of the star formation mode, an observational probe that can be accessed by ALMA over a wide span of cosmic history.
